top_comment.text:
They said up to 800 mph. That doesn't mean they are going to run at Max 
speed all the time. 300 or 400 sounds better for safety purposes.﻿
top_comment.author: MioChan

comments.text:
+Alfred Arzuaga
Eh its in a vacuum or near vacuum, which means no or far less significant 
sound barrier blasting.

Also to @MioChan the whole speed safety thing is kinda silly. Yes 800 mph 
sounds scary, but really, its a straight line closed system with enough 
distance between pods to be able to safely come to a stop, should you have 
to.

You won't have pods traveling the same tube in opposite directions, and the 
pods themselves don't actually touch anything while moving. The real 
dangers would involve a break down in the tube itself, such as a hole in 
the side of it, or some how something got inside the tube, or if for some 
reason, you spike up in G forces because an electrical failure made the 
system think the pressure was different or something.
comments.author: TheJadeFist

comments.text:
Also, It would be a bitch for everyone between San Francisco and Los 
Angeles to be blasted by the sound barrier all day.

comments.author: Aanthanur DC

comments.text:
+Aanthanur DC It simply isn't true that "not very much is needed for a 
solar panel". Until very recently the total energy that could be extracted 
from a solar electric panel within its service life exceeded its embodied 
energy - the energy required to create the panel. Which is to say, you 
couldn't even make a solar powered solar panel factory without external 
energy input. Nowadays they do produce more energy than they cost, but not 
by much. It's still much cheaper to lay miles of copper to supply our 
energy needs, if at all possible.
comments.author: nagualdesign

top_comment.text:
This is not a new idea. In fact in NYC they built one in downtown Manhattan 
in the late 1800's, the Pneumatic Tube Transport (PTT). The US Post Office 
used a similar system to transport mail between Midtown & Downtown 
Manhattan instead of trucks. Both systems were highly successful and died 
because of political reason.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pneumatic_tube
http://www.nycsubway.org/wiki/Beach_Pneumatic_Transit

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pneumatic_tube_mail_in_New_York_City
http://untappedcities.com/2013/03/15/nycs-pneumatic-tube-mail-network/

The entire system runs on a cession of air so they are capable of running 
fast.﻿

top_comment.text: tubes are not cheaper than rails.﻿
top_comment.author: TremereTT

comments.text:
+TremereTT I am not saying it wouldn't be a technical challenge but its 
certainly cheaper than a maglev. The German maglev is an incredibly 
sophisticated and expensive piece of technology, this system would be much 
cheaper because its less complicated and uses less energy.

The Transrapid as a technical exercise is an amazing piece of technology 
but the way the track way is built makes it incredibly costly, it has a 
huge amount of switching gear and power substation and needs a very 
specific type of electromagnet.

I mentioned in a previous post how it levitates, it isn't pushed away from 
the track, its pulled /up/ towards the track from underneath by a magnet 
that is turning off and on rapidly. The whole track way is constantly 
energising and deactivating as well. Several other banks of electromagnets 
are also pulling and pushing it with a kind of electromagnetic "wave" to 
provide its propulsion.

A tube with magnets in would not need to be so sophisticated, just some 
simple electromagnets. They would levitate and propel the carriages simply 
because of the properties of the electromagnets and they would just need to 
be there so to speak, it wouldn't need complicated ones with a a huge 
control and switching system that provide all the clever tricks that make 
the transrapid work.

However I think think there are many other issues other than its technology 
that will stop this project. its too out there for one and people will 
naturally prefer the tried and tested high speed rail which is one of the 
most reliable and safest form of mass transit ever. It could carry cars too 
if there was ever enough demand as the Eurostar is a good example of a road 
and rail system.

It would be dead politically too, there will be a vested interest that 
wants a rail line and they will provide pressure on the authorities with 
lobby groups and so on. 

I am enthusiastic about the technology true but I am enough of a realist to 
understand that this will never see the light of day in this project, it 
might be something that works out elsewhere though.
comments.author: Tuberuser187

comments.text:
Well , you might be a little too enthusiastic about that. We had a 
Transrapid test route in Emsland in Germany and they built this train after 
what felt like 50 years of esperimenting in Germany...they built it in 
Shanghai.
This linear motor is build on poles so you don't need to do all the 
groundworks...
I don't think a tube would be enough and if they choose a strung enough 
tube this tube will be pretty expensive.
A linear motor train is only economic of you have high quantities of 
that.Thats why we never built real transrapid routes. It's just a prestige 
project for china.
On the other hand the first metro of the world was the one in Shanghai, too.

At the end we both lack the blueprints and the numbers to even make an 
educted Guess on the costs site.

It would be cool anyways , with the 800mile/h , because of the USA  #1 
factor. That would propably change the sight of many Americans on the 
importance of public transportation.

It would also kill disneyland and other funfairs....
comments.author: TremereTT

comments.text:
+TremereTT Exactly, at least the basic concept of it. There is undoubtedly 
more to it, possibly even a vacuum or reduced air pressure in the tube 
allowing it to reach its supersonic speed with ease which would add to the 
cost and complexity.

The idea has been around a long time, one of the earliest proposals was 
back when pneumatic trains where a thing.
comments.author: Tuberuser187

comments.text: So you are discribing a linear motor in a tube?
comments.author: TremereTT

comments.text:
+TremereTT It depends on the technology, if it is what I think it is it 
should be fairly cheap compared to high speed rail lines. You can knock 
together a model of it at home, I would bet its a simple tube with embedded 
electromagnets powered by the solar panels and a magnetised vehicle. As its 
a tube the vehicle does not touch the walls of the tube at all as its 
pulled equally in every direction unlike a maglev where the train is pulled 
up towards the track giving the appearance of it "hovering".

When you activate the first set of magnets it flings the vehicle down the 
tube, each set of magnets accelerate it until you near the half way point 
where the polarity reverses and decelerates it. It wouldn't need any more 
maintenance than a rail line and would probably need less as there are no 
impact or friction forces involved, just some corrosion checks on the 
tubing and maybe sending the equivalent of a "geometry train" (the ones 
packed with sensors to check every aspect of a rail line) down once a day 
to check everything is aligned and the magnets are fine.

This is the only technology that would be cheaper, maglev technology is far 
more expensive and costs at minimum 3x the build cost of a high speed rail 
line.

Like any project though there would be hidden costs and unanticipated 
problems and issues, thats of course it is what I think it is as well as it 
might be something else but this would be my best guess as the concept has 
been around for a long time.
comments.author: Tuberuser187

comments.text:
Thats a point. You argued very well.
But I don't think that a tube that is save for a tons heavy object 
traveling 800 miles/h is that cheap to produce and to maintain.

At least you have to admit there is a giant cost risc as there is no data 
you can use to precalculate the finall cost for such an experimental 
system.
comments.author: TremereTT

comments.text:
Of course not but tubes placed on pylons are cheaper than rails, sleepers, 
ballast, overhead power lines and digging out millions of cubic meters of 
soil and rock for the track way in the first place.
comments.author: Tuberuser187

top_comment.text:
Everyone, you must read this article:  
stopandmove.blogspot.com/2013/08/hyperloop-proposal-bad-joke-or-attempt.html

This proposal is a joke designed to derail HSR.  Musk doesn't even include 
the trip from downtown to downtown!  It will actually take LONGER on his 
35-minute tube, which dumps you out on the edge of town.  It's a joke.﻿
top_comment.author: greg55666

comments.text:
+OCDscientist You can't start with motive.  You have to start with the 
proposal itself.  The proposal IS useless and dishonest (or at best 
incompetent).  You must start there, then ask, so WHY did he propose it?

You can't start with a belief that he wouldn't do such a thing and then 
conclude that therefore the proposal has merit.
comments.author: greg55666

comments.text:
+OCDscientist Trains threaten the future of cars.  Even electric cars.  Why 
buy a Tesla Model S if the CA high-speed rail will get you from LA to SF in 
2.5 hours?

Also, for someone like him, I think ego plays a giant part in it.  I do not 
mean that pejoratively, I think it is inevitable when someone has made 2 
billion dollars to want to show you can take on bigger and bigger projects 
yourself.  But if you read that article you can see the idea is 
idiotic--meaning it is a lie--by claiming the low low price he does, he 
simply does not consider the actual difficult things in any large public 
works project.  His train ends 50 miles outside San Francisco!  What good 
does that do anyone?  It's just not a serious proposal.
comments.author: greg55666

comments.text: He doesn't have any possible motive for doing that though

comments.text:
Droidcrasher: Simply due to the fact that it's powered by solar and not 
fossil fuel is a HUGE savings in resources right there. On top of that, the 
vessels will likely be maglev, which means no friction. The amount of money 
spent on maintenance of jets is staggering. From engine wear to tires, it's 
a wonder we use them at all anymore. The same kind of tube can be suspended 
in the ocean for intercontinental travel. Yes there are challenges involved 
as with any developing technology but this is really the way to go for mass 
transportation.
